stem: A 72-year-old male is admitted to the ICU with a confirmed right-sided ischemic stroke. He is receiving tissue plasminogen activator (tPA). Based on the assessment data, prioritize the following interventions in the order of their importance to manage the patient's condition effectively.

itemContext.sbar: S: Robert Miller, 72-year-old male, admitted to ICU at 08:00 with new onset right-sided weakness and slurred speech. Symptoms started around 06:30. NIHSS score was 18 on arrival, indicating moderate to severe stroke. Receiving tPA since 08:30 per stroke protocol. B: PMH includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia, managed with oral medications. No known drug allergies. A: At 09:15, neuro assessment shows GCS 11 (E3, V3, M5). Right-sided weakness persists. Vitals: BP 180/100 mmHg, HR 92 bpm, RR 22 breaths/min, SpO2 94% on 2L NC, Temp 37.2°C. Emesis occurred at 09:10. P: Continuous neuro monitoring is crucial. Aggressively manage BP per stroke protocol, target SBP <180 mmHg. Implement strict aspiration precautions due to GCS and emesis. Prepare for possible intubation/ventilation if GCS declines or respiratory distress occurs. Neurosurgery consult requested.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: Na: 140 mEq/L, K: 4.1 mEq/L, Cl: 100 mEq/L, HCO3: 24 mEq/L, BUN: 18 mg/dL, Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL, Glucose: 110 mg/dL, PT: 14 sec, INR: 1.1, aPTT: 35 sec, Platelets: 250,000/uL, Troponin I: <0.03 ng/mL, WBC: 9,000/uL, Hgb: 14 g/dL, Hct: 42%

tabs.title: Radiology
tabs.content: Head CT scan at 07:00 shows a right-sided ischemic stroke with no evidence of hemorrhage.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: tPA 0.9 mg/kg IV (started at 08:30), Labetalol 20 mg IV PRN for SBP >180 mmHg, Acetaminophen 650 mg PO PRN for Temp >38.3°C, Normal Saline 0.9% IV at 75 mL/hr

rationale.correct: 1. **Administer antihypertensive medication:** The patient's blood pressure of 180/100 mmHg exceeds the target SBP of <180 mmHg per stroke protocol. Rapid BP reduction is vital to prevent further neurological damage and hemorrhagic conversion. 2. **Elevate the head of the bed:** Elevating the head of the bed promotes venous drainage, reducing intracranial pressure (ICP) and improving cerebral perfusion, crucial for neurological compromise. 3. **Monitor neurological status closely:** Continuous neurological assessment is essential to detect changes like worsening GCS or new deficits, enabling timely intervention. 4. **Implement aspiration precautions:** Emesis and decreased GCS increase aspiration risk. Precautions like positioning and suctioning prevent aspiration pneumonia. 5. **Prepare for potential intubation:** A GCS of 11 indicates altered consciousness and airway compromise. Preparing for intubation ensures airway security if deterioration occurs. 6. **Notify the physician of changes in condition:** While important, this follows immediate interventions to stabilize the patient.
rationale.incorrect: Reversing the order leads to improper management. Notifying the physician before stabilizing BP or securing the airway delays critical interventions. Ignoring aspiration risk or not closely monitoring neurological status can lead to severe complications like aspiration pneumonia or undetected ICP increases.
clinicalPearls: In acute stroke, 'time is brain.' Rapid assessment and intervention minimize neurological damage.
Hypertension is common in acute stroke and needs careful management to prevent hemorrhagic conversion.
Changes in GCS require immediate attention, indicating increasing ICP or worsening neurological status.

questionTrap.trap: Many select 'Notify the physician' as a first action. While important, it follows immediate stabilization interventions.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) and immediate actions to stabilize the patient before notifying the physician.

mnemonic.title: BP-HEAD-MAN
mnemonic.expansion: Blood Pressure control, Head elevation, Early neurological assessment, Aspiration precautions, Determine need for intubation, Medical notification after initial stabilization.

options: Elevate the head of the bed
Notify the physician of changes in condition

response.Second: Elevate the head of the bed
response.Last: Notify the physician of changes in condition
